@SETO wrote:

the assumption made that you are using a single core (if you are utilizing more than one core, again you shouldn’t be here [welcome to the graduate class] )
multithreading is not true parallism, at the end of the day your implementation boils down to thread quantum.

any how i am not a fan of java, last time i used it was few months ago at work for cache server and routing implementations

also i haven’t looked at your src, i envy you for what you have made but

item.title: Java Youtube Downloader
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote="_s, post:29, topic:427427"][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=530121.msg3880673#msg3880673 date=1326008841]

[quote author=_s link=topic=530121.msg3880576#msg3880576 date=1326000744]

New design + multi threaded/parallel downloading now.

parallel. sure

if you really saying with the def of parallelism, your sir a one big Albert
[/quote]ok whatever the fuck that meant, i didn’t get it and i’ll assume the worst case of it being a mockery. i doubt this has been parallelised particularly well, but feel free to prove me wrong.

That’s a lot to assume from not being able to see the code, now isn’t it? I’m particularly happy with the new design. Maybe you need a brush up on what being multi-threaded is. See, it is the ability to do more than one task at a time. With the original design, that I doubt you tested, the application locks while downloading. With the new design, you can download more than one video at a time, at the same time, and have the ability to check the download progress on each. It has the options for moving the ‘queue’ up on a video, making it have a greater download rate then another active download. Next time, before trying to sound smart on a programming thread, think a little before you hit the reply + post. It’ll save me the time of replying, and you the time of posting.
[/quote]ok sure you can multithread congratulations that’s a huge achievement rep++!!!2!111#

ps wtf fanclub?!?![/quote]

s1gma squad roll out.

sorry emily I didn’t see you say the world parallel once in your long explanation. multithreading the application is fine and dandy, given that you have multiple cores and the jvm sets the affinity of the thread to a different core for each thread. having a work queue that downloads the files in chunks I think was the point s1gma was getting to or something similar.

I am taking advantage of queue's and the design is truly parallel. Having a greater number of downloads past the usable cores count does not affect performance at all.

doesn’t mean its going to run faster if you have more threads. kinda against the point? no? (lets run 50 threads on a pentium 4 and expect it all to run at different times!) and the chances that each thread is assigned to a core so you get the effect you are looking for:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5879369/java-multithreading-assign-threads-to-processor-cores

somewhere below

You can't. See this article. The JVM will delegate this to the OS, which will handle it for you.

listen to the man because he is more experienced with parallel programming than most of the people here, probally including yourself.

tl;dr

multithreading != parallel workload

Read full topic

item.title: Java Youtube Downloader
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

Lol at Sigma fan club.

I won’t bother quoting everything as that becomes rather disgusting with smf. _s, as I posted in my comment, I am taking advantage of queue’s and the design is truly parallel. Having a greater number of downloads past the usable cores count does not affect performance at all. Rather, it just moves the priority/download rate of the newly added to queue downloads to a lower rate while accumulating this difference by taking a smaller percentage off the average rate of the first in queue downloads.

At people saying why are you commenting at Sigma, ect, ect, ect. You do realize that no one on here is a god figure, nor has the knowledge to be treated as so. If someone is wrong, or acting childish, I have full rights to say as I please. The majority of you, excluding Omer and Hadyn, don’t even have a grasp on programming so you aren’t involved into this conversation either. I think you are forgetting who commented against who. It is called using defensive argument, should look into it.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Youtube Downloader
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:25, topic:427427”][quote author=_s link=topic=530121.msg3880576#msg3880576 date=1326000744]

New design + multi threaded/parallel downloading now.

parallel. sure

if you really saying with the def of parallelism, your sir a one big Albert
[/quote]ok whatever the fuck that meant, i didn’t get it and i’ll assume the worst case of it being a mockery. i doubt this has been parallelised particularly well, but feel free to prove me wrong.

That’s a lot to assume from not being able to see the code, now isn’t it? I’m particularly happy with the new design. Maybe you need a brush up on what being multi-threaded is. See, it is the ability to do more than one task at a time. With the original design, that I doubt you tested, the application locks while downloading. With the new design, you can download more than one video at a time, at the same time, and have the ability to check the download progress on each. It has the options for moving the ‘queue’ up on a video, making it have a greater download rate then another active download. Next time, before trying to sound smart on a programming thread, think a little before you hit the reply + post. It’ll save me the time of replying, and you the time of posting.[/quote]ok sure you can multithread congratulations that’s a huge achievement rep++!!!2!111#

as a recommendation, think about concurrent design properly. i wouldn’t mind betting that you’re firing off a new thread for every concurrently downloaded video, which is fine when downloads <= usable_cores but not so clever for large workloads. what you could do is queue up operations and execute usable_cores operations at a time with an underlying threadpool. that would be half decent parallelisation of the workload

ps wtf fanclub?!?!

Read full topic

item.title: Java Youtube Downloader
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:16, topic:427427”]of course yours is fine its not the same program

works but downloads the whole video i was expecting sound only
anyways gj[/quote]

It is the same program, just different design. By looking through the code you would see that it downloads it into mp4 format (in the original release). My newer client is just an expansion on the last version, which handles more sites, different formats, ect. Rsbuddy developers have suggested I include options for searching, recording, uploading, ect. I’ll see if I ever get around to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Youtube Downloader
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:19, topic:427427”][quote author=RandQm link=topic=530121.msg3874056#msg3874056 date=1325538941]

It says invalid url everytime
I tried
http: //www.youtube .com/wat ch?v=0VmUYE4Jhqk (putting spaces to not display as vid :p)
www.youtu be.com/wa tch?v=0VmU YE4Jhqk (putting spaces to not display as vid :p)
watch?v=0VmUYE4Jhqk
0VmUYE4Jhqk
mUYE4Jhqk

none of em is working
any suggestions?

I assume you are most likely entering it in the video Id field instead of the convert field, you only need to put the video id into the video id field.

Your video id for that video is 0VmUYE4Jhqk


[/quote]

Stop clicking convert, and click the big download button at the bottom.

Edit:

Downloads fine…
[/quote]

of course yours is fine its not the same program

works but downloads the whole video i was expecting sound only
anyways gj

Read full topic

item.title: Java Youtube Downloader
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:14, topic:427427”][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=530121.msg3870697#msg3870697 date=1325314428]

Compare what sources, t4? What I posted is just standard download code with support for percentages

Adding a working progress bar would have been about an extra 4 lines of code…try { private int downloaded = 0; URLConnection uc = new URL("derpy").openConnection(); int fileSize = uc.getContentLength(); if(fileSize < 1) { return; } BufferedInputStream in = new BufferedInputStream(uc.getInputStream()); byte[] b = new byte[1024]; FileOutputStream out = new FileOutputStream(new File("derpy")); int length; while ((length = in.read(b)) > 0) { out.write(b, 0, length); downloaded += length; //percent = 100 * (downloaded/fileSize); cast to double correctly to avoid decimal truncating } } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); }

The process for downloading causes the application to lock until the download is complete. So by telling the progress bar to update its initial value, it will not update until after the download is complete. Well, before I split the processing into separate threads it did that. Refer to the newer pic.
[/quote]I am aware, which is why the code I posted is actually from inside the run method of a runnable class I have to download stuff from my RSPS client (obviously with some code removed that was client specific, and some useless stuff for you like the download speed with time remaining etc)

Having a progress bar, especially for higher size downloading, is very vital to the average user. Did you remove it in that second picture or can I just not see it?

i was referring to the fact you asked why he didn’t include it - i was implying he didn’t write this as a semi-troll.

She, and what would be the point of posting something if I didn’t write it. You obviously don’t know who I am lol.

a lot of kids post things they’ve not written on this side; and no, i do not know who you are - doesn’t really matter either.[/quote]

this entire conversation, lol

Read full topic
